#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER XVI .
#Text=WEDNESDAY MADNESS
#Text=How long he was “ kept in ” after school that afternoon is not a matter of record ; but it was long .
#Text=Before he finally appeared upon the street , he had composed an ample letter on a subject of general interest , namely “ School Life ” , under the supervision of Miss Spencer .

#Text=He had also received some scorching admonitions in respect to honourable behaviour regarding other people 's letters ; and Margaret 's had been returned to him with severe instructions to bear it straight to the original owner accompanied by full confession and apology .
#Text=As a measure of insurance that these things be done , Miss Spence stated definitely her intention to hold a conversation by telephone with Margaret that evening .
#Text=Altogether , the day had been unusually awful , even for Wednesday , and Penrod left the school-house with the heart of an anarchist throbbing in his hot bosom .
#Text=It were more accurate , indeed , to liken him to the anarchist 's characteristic weapon ; for as Penrod came out to the street he was , in all inward respects , a bomb , loaded and ticking .
#Text=He walked moodily , with a visible aspect of soreness .

#Text=A murmurous sound was thick about his head , wherefore it is to be surmised that he communed with his familiar , and one vehement , oft-repeated phrase beat like a tocsin of revolt upon the air :
#Text=“ Daw-gone ' em ! ”
#Text=He meant everybody -- the universe .
#Text=Particularly included , evidently , was a sparrow , offensively cheerful upon a lamp-post .

#Text=This self-centred little bird allowed a pebble to pass overhead and remained unconcerned , but , a moment later , feeling a jar beneath his feet , and hearing the tinkle of falling glass , he decided to leave .
#Text=Similarly , and at the same instant , Penrod made the same decision , and the sparrow in flight took note of a boy likewise in flight .
#Text=The boy disappeared into the nearest alley and emerged therefrom , breathless , in the peaceful vicinity of his own home .
#Text=He entered the house , clumped upstairs and down , discovered Margaret reading a book in the library , and flung the accursed letter toward her with loathing .
#Text=“ You can take the old thing , ” he said bitterly .
#Text=“ I do n't want it ! ”
#Text=And before she was able to reply , he was out of the room .
#Text=The next moment he was out of the house .
#Text=“ Daw-GONE ' em ! ” he said .

#Text=And then , across the street , his soured eye fell upon his true comrade and best friend leaning against a picket fence and holding desultory converse with Mabel Rorebeck , an attractive member of the Friday Afternoon Dancing Class , that hated organization of which Sam and Penrod were both members .
#Text=Mabel was a shy little girl ; but Penrod had a vague understanding that Sam considered her two brown pig-tails beautiful .
#Text=Howbeit , Sam had never told his love ; he was , in fact , sensitive about it .

#Text=This meeting with the lady was by chance , and , although it afforded exquisite moments , his heart was beating in an unaccustomed manner , and he was suffering from embarrassment , being at a loss , also , for subjects of conversation .

#Text=It is , indeed , no easy matter to chat easily with a person , however lovely and beloved , who keeps her face turned the other way , maintains one foot in rapid and continuous motion through an arc seemingly perilous to her equilibrium , and confines her responses , both affirmative and negative , to “ Uh-huh . ”

#Text=Altogether , Sam was sufficiently nervous without any help from Penrod , and it was with pure horror that he heard his own name and Mabel 's shrieked upon the ambient air with viperish insinuation .
#Text=“ Sam-my and May-bul !
#Text=OH , oh ! ”
#Text=Sam started violently .
#Text=Mabel ceased to swing her foot , and both , encarnadined , looked up and down and everywhere for the invisible but well-known owner of that voice .
#Text=It came again , in taunting mockery :
#Text=“ Sammy 's mad , and I am glad , And I know what will please him : A bottle o ' wine to make him shine , And Mabel Rorebeck to squeeze him ! ”
#Text=“ Fresh ole thing ! ” said Miss Rorebeck , becoming articulate .
#Text=And unreasonably including Sam in her indignation , she tossed her head at him with an unmistakable effect of scorn .
#Text=She began to walk away .
#Text=“ Well , Mabel , ” Sam said plaintively , following , “ it ai n't MY fault .
#Text=I did n't do anything .
#Text=It 's Penrod . ”
#Text=“ I do n't care , ” she began pettishly , when the viperish voice was again lifted :
#Text=“ Oh , oh , oh ! Who 's your beau ?
#Text=Guess I know : Mabel and Sammy , oh , oh , oh ! I caught you ! ”
#Text=Then Mabel did one of those things that eternally perplex the slower sex .
#Text=She deliberately made a face , not at the tree behind which Penrod was lurking , but at the innocent and heart-wrung Sam .
#Text=“ You need n't come limpin ' after me , Sam Williams ! ” she said , though Sam was approaching upon two perfectly sound legs .
#Text=And then she ran away at the top of her speed .
#Text=“ Run , rigger , run ! ”
#Text=Penrod began inexcusably .
#Text=But Sam cut the persecutions short at this point .
#Text=Stung to fury , he charged upon the sheltering tree in the Schofields ' yard .
#Text=Ordinarily , at such a juncture , Penrod would have fled , keeping his own temper and increasing the heat of his pursuer 's by back-flung jeers .
#Text=But this was Wednesday , and he was in no mood to run from Sam .
#Text=He stepped away from the tree , awaiting the onset .
#Text=“ Well , what you goin ' to do so much ? ” he said .
#Text=Sam did not pause to proffer the desired information .
#Text=“ ' Tcha got'ny SENSE ! ” was the total extent of his vocal preliminaries before flinging himself headlong upon the taunter ; and the two boys went to the ground together .
#Text=Embracing , they rolled , they pommelled , they hammered , they kicked .
#Text=Alas , this was a fight .
